Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response & Recovery

Understanding the Impact of Natural Disasters on Children

A study published in August 2020 by the Society for Research in Child Development looked at the impact of natural disasters on children. Here are the findings.

Every year, 175 million children globally are expected to be affected by natural disasters

Children are most vulnerable to immediate physical effects of disasters due to breathing more air per pound, having thinner skin, being at greater risk of fluid loss and loss of body heat, and the indirect effects of an eroding support system.

Children are more vulnerable to long term physical effects. 9-18% show acute illness after a disaster.

Children are more vulnerable to mental health issues after a disaster. 50% report post traumatic stress symptoms. Chronic mental health symptoms can last for up to 4 years.

Children who have experienced a natural disaster are more likely to have lower school attendance and trouble learning.
